Certainly! Here are some references and bibliography suggestions that you may find helpful:

1. Gombrich, E. H. (1960). Art and Illusion: A Study in the Psychology of Pictorial Representation. Princeton University Press.
2. Lakoff, G., & Johnson, M. (1980). Metaphors We Live By. University of Chicago Press.
3. Saussure, F. de. (2011). Course in General Linguistics. Columbia University Press.
4. Hockett, C. F. (1958). A Course in Modern Linguistics. Macmillan.
5. Whorf, B. L. (1956). Language, Thought, and Reality: Selected Writings. MIT Press.
6. Gibson, J. J. (1979). The Ecological Approach to Visual Perception. Houghton Mifflin.
7. Kandinsky, W. (1977). Concerning the Spiritual in Art. Dover Publications.
8. Arnheim, R. (1974). Art and Visual Perception: A Psychology of the Creative Eye. University of California Press.
9. Tufte, E. R. (1990). Envisioning Information. Graphics Press.
10. de Bono, E. (1967). The Use of Lateral Thinking. Penguin.

These books explore various aspects of the relationship between language, form, and art, including the role of language in shaping perception, the use of forms and structures in visual art and design, and the ways in which different forms of expression can be used to communicate ideas and emotions.
